Detailed Description

Data model provides above-session data modeling.

Description

The data model provides a way to use data between the backend server, the database and the front end HTML objects in a way that is non-ambiguous, safe and easy.

Author:
Elliot Chance
Since:
1.0

Definition at line 24 of file CMDataModel.php.

Member Function Documentation

addPool ( $  name,
$  replace = false 
)

Add a new pool.

Parameters:
$name The name of the new pool.
$replace If true and the pool already exists it will be replaced with a blank pool. The default is false - the pool will not be modified if it already exists.
Returns:
Always true.

Definition at line 596 of file CMDataModel.php.

button ( $  name,
$  a = false 
)

Render a non-submit form button.

This function is an alias of CMForm::Button with the only difference being that the the HTML object value is supplied from the pool.

Note:
If $a['name'] or $a['value'] is provided it will be replaced before rendering the object.
Parameters:
$name The name of the button that also determines the pool and variable of where the data comes from.
$a The options to be passed directly to CMForm.

Definition at line 856 of file CMDataModel.php.

checkboxGroup ( $  name,
$  a = false 
)

Render a group of checkboxes.

This function is an alias of CMForm::CheckboxGroup with the only difference being that the the HTML object value is supplied from the pool.

Note:
The value is transalated into the selected value, rather than the values of the checkboxes. You are expected to also provide an array of radio items.
If $a['name'] or $a['value'] is provided it will be replaced before rendering the object.
Parameters:
$name The name of the checkbox group that also determines the pool and variable of where the data comes from.
$a The options to be passed directly to CMForm.

Definition at line 920 of file CMDataModel.php.

CMDataModel ( $  name = 'default'  ) 

Create or restore a data model.

If the data model does not exist it will be created.

Parameters:
$name The model name attached to this session, if this is not provided it will use/create a pool named default.

Definition at line 113 of file CMDataModel.php.

static CreateDataModel ( $  name = 'default',
$  force = false 
) [static]

Create a new data model.

Parameters:
$name Name of the new data model.
$force If this is true and a data model of $name already exists then it will be replaced with a new data model.
Returns:
The newly created data model object.

Definition at line 649 of file CMDataModel.php.

databaseDelete ( $  tableName,
$  filter,
$  a = false 
)

Perform a database DELETE.

This method works in the same way as databaseInsert() with the difference it performs an equivilent DELETE using CMDatabaseProtocol::delete().

See databaseInsert() for more information.

Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the database handle is invalid.
Parameters:
$tableName The name of the table to update.
$filter An associative array to be used in the WHERE clause.
$a Extra options passed to CMDatabaseProtocol::delete().
See also:
databaseInsert()
databaseUpdate()

Definition at line 579 of file CMDataModel.php.

databaseInsert ( $  tableName,
$  fields = 'auto',
$  a = false 
)

Perform a database INSERT.

This method simply provides a bridge between a pool or an associative array of data and the CMDatabaseProtocol::insert() method. This means that all the fields in the pool or array provided by $fields will be passed to the insert(). If there are any fields in the pool or array keys that do no directly match fields in the table the result SQL will most likely fail.

Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the database handle is invalid.
Parameters:
$tableName The name of the table to INSERT into.
$fields If the $fields are 'auto' (or not supplied) we use the pool that is the same name as the table.
$a Extra options passed to CMDatabaseProtocol::insert().
Returns:
On success the return value from the insert() will be passed on. This will be the newly created primary key. But be careful since 0 is a possible generated primary key. Use false to exact compare against or check the error stack to make sure the statement didn't fail.
See also:
databaseUpdate()
databaseDelete()

Definition at line 514 of file CMDataModel.php.

databaseUpdate ( $  tableName,
$  filter,
$  fields = 'auto',
$  a = false 
)

Perform a database UPDATE.

This method works in the same way as databaseInsert() with the difference it performs an equivilent UPDATE using CMDatabaseProtocol::update().

See databaseInsert() for more information.

Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the database handle is invalid.
Parameters:
$tableName The name of the table to update.
$filter An associative array to be used in the WHERE clause.
$fields Field data.
$a Extra options passed to CMDatabaseProtocol::update().
See also:
databaseInsert()
databaseDelete()

Definition at line 665 of file CMDataModel.php.

deletePool ( $  name  ) 

Delete a pool.

Note:
You are not allowed to delete the 'public' pool. If you wish to reset it use drainPool('public').
Parameters:
$name The pool name.
Returns:
true.

Definition at line 1060 of file CMDataModel.php.

drainPool ( $  name = 'public'  ) 

Drain (reset, wipe, clear) a pool or pools of all its variables.

This will also drain the validator of the fields that apply to this pool(s).

Throws a CMError Notice
See CMError::throwNotice(). For each pool that doesn't exist.
Parameters:
$name The name of the pool or and array of pool names.

Definition at line 312 of file CMDataModel.php.

extractNameValue ( $  name  ) 

Extract the bare name and real value from a variable.

This is mostly and internal method, it is public because other classes need to use it.

Parameters:
$name The variable unspecific to any pool.
Returns:
A two element array of the bare name and value. If the variable doesn't exist in the pool NULL is returned for the second array element.

A human-readable explanation of why the validation failed.

Parameters:
$name The name of the field. If the field did validate "" is returned, otherwise the short human-readable error message.

$  name = 'public' 
)

Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the pool doesn't exist.
Parameters:
$values Associative array of objects to append/replace in the pool.
$name An optional name of the pool, if this is not supplied the 'default' pool will will be used.
See also:
setPool()

Definition at line 615 of file CMDataModel.php.

get ( $  name,
$  pool = 'public' 
)

Get a variable from a pool.

Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the pool does not exist.
Parameters:
$name The name of the variable.
$pool An optional argument to specify the pool name, if no argument is given then the 'public pool will be used.
Returns:
If the variable exists in the pool the value will be returned, if the variable does not exist NULL is returned.
See also:
set()
request()

listBox ( $  name,
$  a = false 
)

Render a list.

This function is an alias of CMForm::ListBox with the only difference being that the the HTML object value is supplied from the pool.

Note:
The value is transalated into the selected value, rather than the values of the list box items. You are expected to also provide an array of list box items.
If $a['name'] or $a['value'] is provided it will be replaced before rendering the object.
Parameters:
$name The name of the list box that also determines the pool and variable of where the data comes from.
$a The options to be passed directly to CMForm.

Definition at line 899 of file CMDataModel.php.

recordExists ( $  pool,
$  tableName = false,
$  extra = array() 
)

Check if a table contains one or more records where all the values in a pool match a single databse row.

For example if the pool was; 

 (
   'username' => 'bobsmith',
   'password' => 'abc123',
   'type' => 5
 )

The result SQL would be: 

 SELECT COUNT(1) FROM mytable WHERE username='bobsmith' AND password='abc123' AND type=5;
Parameters:
$pool The name of the pool.
$tableName The database table name. This is optional, if not supplied the table name will be the same as the pool name.
$extra An associative array of extra fields to add to the WHERE clause.
Returns:
true if count() returns 1 record or more, otherwise false. If the pool does not exist false will also be returned. If there is no database handle false will also be returned.

Definition at line 1019 of file CMDataModel.php.

redirect ( $  url,
$  values = array() 
)

Redirect page location.

This method will only work if no data has been written to the page. This method is a convienient alias for CMHeader::Location().

Parameters:
$url The location do direct the user to.
$values Substitute values passed directly to CMHeader::Location().
Returns:
Nothing.
See also:
CMHeader::Location()

Definition at line 301 of file CMDataModel.php.

request ( $  name  ) 

Request a variable from the $_GET or $_POST.

This method makes it easier to return $_GET and $_POST values by returning the $_GET if available, if not the $_POST if available, if not NULL.

Parameters:
$name The name of the variable.
Returns:
The value if it can be found, otherwise NULL.

Definition at line 781 of file CMDataModel.php.

set ( $  name,
$  value = false,
$  pool = 'public' 
)

Set a variable in a pool.

If the variable does not exist it will be created, if it does exist the value will be replaced. If the pool does not exist, NULL will be returned and the variable will be discarded.

Throws a CMError Warning
See CMError::throwWarning(). If the pool doesn't exist.
Parameters:
$name The name of the variable.
$value The value of any type. If this is not specified false will be used.
$pool The pool name. If this is not specified the default 'public' pool will be used.
Returns:
If the assignment was successful the same valeu will be returned. If the assignment failed, NULL is returned.
See also:
get()
request()

Definition at line 225 of file CMDataModel.php.

Set the database handle.

Parameters:
$database Active database handle.
Returns:
true
See also:

hasDatabase()

$  value = false 
)

$value The value of any type. If this is not specified, false will be used.
Returns:

Definition at line 329 of file CMDataModel.php.

setPool ( array $  values,
$  name = 'default' 
)

Replace a pool with an array.

If the pool does not exist it will created, if it does exist it will be replaced by the content in $values.

Parameters:
$values An associative array of values to set the pool to.
$name The name of the pool.
Returns:
Always true.

Definition at line 975 of file CMDataModel.php.

setPools ( array $  pools  ) 

Set multiple pools.

If any of the pools do not exist they will be created.

Parameters:
$pools An associative array of pool names as keys.
Returns:
Always true.

Submit to a previous location.

Definition at line 103 of file CMDataModel.php.

$pool = array() [private]

Storage pools.

By default there are three pools called 'public', 'get' and 'post' where the last two are automatically filled and maintained by the $_GET and $_POST data respectivly.

See also:
set()
get()
addPool()
deletePool()
renamePool()
